texts.shortText:
Pycnogonids are bizarre animals sometimes referred to as ‘sea-spiders’ since both groups have 4 pairs of usually elongate, slender legs. However, they are not closely-related to true spiders, so we prefer the term pycnogonid. The body consists of a head with a tubular proboscis, usually a pair of grasping chelicerae, a pair of sensory palps and a pair of ovigerous legs. The latter are unique to this group and used both for grooming and, in the males, to carry the eggs. Behind the head is an elongate trunk consisting of usually four segments, each of which bears large lateral processes to which the legs are attached. At the end of the trunk is a small, usually conical abdomen.

This species is a particularly strange and distinctive one. It has an unusually stout body and legs and is bright pink or orange in colour. The first body segment is broadly triangular and inflated into three anterior knobs, while the head and tapering proboscis are downwardly flexed and invisible from above. The entire body and legs are covered with tiny conical spines. The legs are unusual in that they end in a single simple claw (most pycnogonids have a pair of auxilliary claws on either side of the main terminal claw).

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.

Very little work has been done on the biology of South African pycnogonids, but this species has found on rocky shores, and more commonly on gorgonians. Barnard records it as being common in False Bay where ‘almost every piece of fan-coral (Gorgonia fammea – now Leptogorgia palma) which I have examined in a fresh state, has one or more of these little pycnogonids clasping its branches’. He also records it on several other genera of branching seafans, suggesting that it feeds on these, although he also reports specimens from in the intertidal zone among hydroids and bryozoans.

Almost all pycnogonids feed on cnidarians and this unusual species is most often found on branching seafans, on which it is presumed to feed. The pink or orange colour would blend in with this substratum and the short strong legs would be an adaptation to gripping the branches of seafans.

Pycnogonids have unusual reproductive habits.  The sexes are separate and since the body is so narrow, the gonads extend into the legs. The femurs of females may thus become conspicuously enlarged when gravid. There are reproductive openings on all the legs of females and on legs 2 and 4 of males. As the female releases her eggs these are fertilised by the male, who then gathers them up and carries them in a spherical mass attached to his ovigerous legs until they hatch.
Easily distinguished from other local species by the unusual pink or orange colour, short compact body, swollen first body segment and spiky texture.
Barnard, KH (1954). South African Pycnogonida. Annals of the South African Museum, 39, 81-159.
